```
Task1 100% |████████████████████████████████|
Task2 50%  |███████████████                                                               |
```
Also I will add a flag `--progress-bar` for users to run backfill by hand so that it will not pollute the logs during normal backfill
You should be good to go :)

ping @djo10  :)

@imroc You are correct, the query won't be committed for MySqlHook.run() even autocommit is set to `True`. Did some researches an I'm pretty sure it is because MySql [set autocommit in a different way](https://github.com/PyMySQL/mysqlclient-python/blob/master/MySQLdb/connections.py#L249-L256). It should be `conn.autocommit(True)` instead of `conn.autocommit = True` like others. 

I shall do a quick PR to fix that. ETA tomorrow night.
I like the code change, it looks much cleaner.
@saguziel Please do the development on your own Travis. We've had some complaints by Apache Infra of using too much CPU time on Travis. Thanks!
Yes, I really appreciatie that you take the time to make this cleaner and simpler :)

How `AIRFLOW_HOME` is set, read and used is actually not the concern of bash operator--testing the process end to end would add dependency on `AIRFLOW_HOME` reading logic in configuration.py to bash operator test( to figure out the precise value to export), which is out of the scope.

@mistercrunch @bolkedebruin my only concern is that if the DAG has too many tasks or the backfill has too many DAG runs and we cannot fit all of them in the console and it become useless.

How about we have two bars?
```
DAG run completed 100% |████████████████████████████████|
Tasks completed   50%  |███████████████                                                               |
```

@jgao54 For the `task_instance` table dag_id+task_id+execution_date is the composite primary key, correct.

But for `task_fail` table it's different. In the DB the primary key is `id` with a DB sequence, see the [migration script](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/migrations/versions/64de9cddf6c9_add_task_fails_journal_table.py#L47) and the schema below. The table and the model class were introduced in #1712, there you can see that the model class and the migration script don't match. My guess is that the model class was copied form the TaskInstance class. (I just see another thing, the `duration` column is defined as float in the model class but as integer in the DB)

For each failed attempt a [row is added](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L1721) to the `task_fail` table, which somehow already works with the existing code. Until now there is no code that retrieves data from `task_fail`. I just noticed the issue when I tried to retrieve all failed attempts for a task instance that I only received one but in the DB there were multiple, I guess sqlalchemy did some filtering based on the model definition.

If you prefer I can first create a separate Jira and PR to discuss and fix the DB schema and model class issue.


```
                                         Table "public.task_fail"
     Column     |           Type           | Collation | Nullable |                Default                
----------------+--------------------------+-----------+----------+---------------------------------------
 id             | integer                  |           | not null | nextval('task_fail_id_seq'::regclass)
 task_id        | character varying(250)   |           | not null | 
 dag_id         | character varying(250)   |           | not null | 
 execution_date | timestamp with time zone |           | not null | 
 start_date     | timestamp with time zone |           |          | 
 end_date       | timestamp with time zone |           |          | 
 duration       | integer                  |           |          | 
Indexes:
    "task_fail_pkey" PRIMARY KEY, btree (id)
```

Just a sidenote,
Running on an operating system without /bin in $PATH gives a ``[FATAL tini (8)] exec bash failed: No such file or directory`` error. For example, (unless I've misconfigured up my OS) I don't believe Arch linux has /bin in $PATH by default.

I fixed it by adding 
``- PATH=${PATH}:/bin``
to the docker-compose.yaml, under the similar command for ``/usr/bin/hive``
@yrqls21  nice
@Fokko @imroc @artwr PTAL

now after this change,  i wonder how do we identify if a file is a DAG file. for example, if a file without "DAG", do we still consider a DAG file? If I understand correctly, it will import any python file under the dagbag directory even without the DAG keyword?

@feng-tao there is no easy way without parsing and executing the code to know whether a Python file loads a DAG object into its globals. The regex/string matching version is a cheap alternative to actual parsing + execution.
I should say because of this I am a -1 on this for now, because I know for a fact that this might mess up the DagBags for a few people.

Can you explain how this will mess up DagBags for people? In the worst case, this could increase processing time for people who put many non-dag Python files in the top-level directory; however, I don't see how this would cause incorrect execution except in exceptional circumstances.

There is a .airflowignore file supported if you want to skip specific files.

On the other hand, it is counter-intuitive for processing of a zip file to stop simply because one file in it does not have the words "DAG" and "airflow". It's even worse for this to happen silently.

>> Can you explain how this will mess up DagBags for people? In the worst case, this could increase processing time for people who put many non-dag Python files in the top-level directory;

Sorry, it was more of a drive by comment, by mess up, I meant operationally, as it might result in a larger number of files parsed, but not that it would prevent Dags from being loaded. Some colocated python scripts could call an expensive resource (and we have seen this in the past). It also not only the top level directory since we are doing an os.walk in collect_dags.

I agree that the check probably needs to be refined, but it does not seem completely crazy that the words airflow/DAG should be in a module creating a DAG, if only in a docstring at the top of the file. It is definitely good to document/we could expand the actual check though to more than just those two strings. 

`.airflowignore` is fine, but it does not address the issue at hand as it is more of a dev facility than a production one. You would have to add all the non dag files which you want to ignore there. What happens if someone has a DAG file named the same as the script you are trying to exclude...?

Complete agreed with you on the zipfile front, the check should probably look into all files, and if any are found, return. I would welcome a PR which would make that change.
